Depletion of PMN leukocytes increases fungal loads and
mortality rates of TL2-deficient but not normal mice

The finding that PMN cells were abundantly recruited to the
lungs of TLR2?/? mice in the presence of diminished fungal
growth led us to verify whether these cells had a significant
antifungal effector function in our model of pulmonary PCM.
Thus, TLR2?/? and TLR2?/? mice were in vivo depleted of
PMN cells by a polyclonal Ab and infected i.t. with the fungus.
By days 2 and 6 after infection, PMN-depleted TLR2?/? but
not normal mice presented increased fungal burdens in the
lungs (Fig. 6, A and B). The protective effect of PMN cells to
deficient mice was confirmed by the precocious mortality de-
veloped by PMN-depleted mice. By day 5 of infection, 50% of
PMN-depleted TLR2?/? mice died, although no deaths were
observed in the PMN-depleted WT group (Fig. 6C). We have
also evaluated the killing ability of alveolar PMN cells obtained
from P. brasiliensis-infected mice. At week 2 of infection, air-
way PMN cells were obtained from TLR2?/? and normal mice
and in vitro challenged with yeast cells (2:1, PMN:yeast ratio)
for 1 h. As can be seen in Fig. 6C, equivalent numbers of viable
yeast cells were recovered from both mouse strains, indicating
that PMN cells from TLR2-deficient mice did not have an in-
creased killing ability when compared with those from normal
mice. Hence, the higher CFU counts detected in PMN-depleted
TLR2?/? mice could be attributed to the higher influx of PMN
leukocytes to the lungs but not to an intrinsically enhanced
killing ability of these cells.

TLR deficiency determines diminished T cell reactivity and
influx to the lungs

We have further analyzed the phenotype and activity of lung in-
flammatory cells of TLR2?/? and WT mice infected i.t. with 1
million P. brasiliensis yeast cells. To determine the activation pro-
file of pulmonary macrophages, the expression of CD11b, MHC
class II (I-Ak), CD80, CD86, and CD40 Ags was assayed by flow
cytometry. As can be seen in Fig. 7, no differences in lung mac-
rophages were detected at weeks 2 and 11 of infection. The phe-
notypic analysis of lymphocyte subsets was also performed. Thus,
the expression of CD4, CD25, CD8, and CD69 molecules was
studied in lung-infiltrating lymphocytes. As depicted in Fig. 7A, at
week 2 of infection, no differences in the number and activation of
T cells were observed. However, a decreased frequency of acti-
vated CD4? T lymphocytes expressing CD25 (CD4?CD25?) was
detected in TLR2?/? animals at this period of infection (data not
shown). By week 11, however, significantly decreased numbers of
CD4?, CD8?, and CD8?CD69? T cells were detected in
TLR2?/? animals (Fig. 7B).

TLR2-deficient mice develop a Th17-skewed T cell response

Because the equilibrium between pro- and anti-inflammatory cy-
tokines determines the efficiency and cellular composition of in-
flammatory reactions (30) and because recent investigations have
demonstrated an increased presence of PMN cells associated with
prevalent IL-17 secretion (31), cytokines associated with Th1 (IL-
12, TNF-?, IL-2, and IFN-?), Th2 (IL-4, IL-5, and IL-10), and
Th17 (TGF-?, IL-6, IL-17, and IL-23) immunity were assessed in
lung homogenates obtained at different periods of infection (Figs.
8 and 9A). However, 48 h after infection, at the innate phase of
immunity, higher levels of TGF-? and IL-17 were detected in the
lungs of TLR2-deficient mice. At week 2, this strain produced
higher amounts of IL-6, TGF-?, IL-17, and IL-23. By week 11,
TLR2?/? mice showed a sustained increase of IL-23 associated
with lowered concentrations of IL-10 and IL-12. We have further
defined the phenotype of IL-17-producing cells. As shown in Fig.
9B, after 72 h and 2 wk of P brasiliensis infection, significantly
increased numbers of IL-17?CD4? T cells were detected in the
lungs of TLR2?/? mice. No differences were observed in the total
numbers of CD8? T cells, although the frequency of this T cell
subset was significantly augmented in TLR2-deficient mice. These
findings demonstrate that TLR2 deficiency induces, since the early
phase of pulmonary infection, a Th17-skewed immune response,
without severely impairing Th1 and Th2 immunity.

TLR2 deficiency results in lower expansion of
CD4?CD25?FoxP3? Tregs

In murine candidiasis, TLR2 deficiency was associated with de-
creased IL-10 production and deficient expansion of CD4? Tregs
(4, 32). In addition, differentiation of Tregs has an inhibitory effect
on Th17 expansion (33, 34). Although Th17 cells and Tregs re-
quire TGF-? to their differentiation, the concomitant presence of
some proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-1 or IL-6 results in
preferential development of Th17 cells and impaired Treg expan-
sion (34). These findings led us to ask whether the prevalent Th17

immunity developed by TLR2-defficient mice was associated with
decreased expansion and recruitment of Tregs to the lungs. Thus,
TLR2?/? and WT mice were sacrificed at weeks 2 and 11 after
infection and the presence of CD4?CD25?FoxP3? T cells was
characterized by flow cytometry in the CD4? subpopulation of
lung-infiltrating lymphocytes. Surface staining of CD25? and in-
tracellular FoxP3? expression was back-gated on the CD4? T cell
population. As can be seen in Fig. 10, no differences were detected
at week 2 but, at week 11 a lower number of CD4?CD25?FoxP3?

T cells was observed in the lung inflammatory lymphocytes of
TLR2-deficient than in WT mice.

Discussion
Recent studies have established the central role of TLRs in the
innate immune recognition of a wide variety of microorganisms,
including fungal pathogens (12, 15, 17). Since the contribution of
TLR in P. brasiliensis infection was never investigated, the present
report assessed the role of TLR2 in the innate and acquired phases
of immunity to this pulmonary fungal pathogen. Data here pre-
sented demonstrate that TLR2 promotes fungal infection, but it has
a concomitant beneficial effect to the host due to its inhibitory
effect on the development of inflammatory reactions associated
with prevalent Th17 immunity. Furthermore, it was also shown
that TLR2 activation positively controls the expansion of Tregs,
which modulate innate and adaptive immune cells and restrain
lung inflammatory pathology.

Although TLR usually do not mediate fungal uptake (35), our in
vitro studies suggested that P. brasiliensis yeast cells use TLR2 to
interact with macrophages and to activate innate immunity cells. P.
brasiliensis yeast cells appear to be recognized by TLR2 mole-
cules, resulting in increased adherence/ingestion and augmented
production of NO and cytokines (IL-10 and MCP-1). Despite this
increased activation, 48 h after infection an increased number of
viable fungi were recovered from TLR2-normal cells. This finding

appears to be paradoxical, since the killing ability of murine mac-
rophages was previously reported to be associated with NO pro-
duction by cytokine-stimulated phagocytes (36). Although the kill-
ing mechanisms were not here addressed, it appears that the
increased NO secretion by TLR2-normal macrophages was not
sufficient to abolish the increased fungal interaction mediated by
TLR2 expression. Furthermore, the concomitant increase in IL-10
production could have inhibited the fungicidal ability of TLR2-
normal macrophages. Along the same line, we could hypothesize
that the lower IL-10 synthesis by TLR2?/? macrophages would

enhance IDO activity which would control P .brasiliensis growth
and inhibit inducible NO synthase activity. This possibility is un-
der investigation in our laboratory and would accommodate the
lower fungal loads and NO production observed with TLR2?/?

macrophages (16, 30). Similarly to our results, TLR2-deficient
macrophages exhibited an increased ability to contain another fun-
gal pathogen, C. albicans, but this fact was not associated with
different patterns of cytokine production (37).

The in vivo infection of TLR2-deficient mice resulted in de-
creased fungal burdens in all postinfection periods assayed. The
less severe infection was always associated with low NO produc-
tion. Again, the differences in fungal burdens could be explained
by the different fungal interaction with alveolar macrophages at
early phases of infection and not by differences in NO secretion.
Forty-eight hours after infection, production of pulmonary cyto-
kines was similar in both mouse strains, except for the augmented
synthesis of TGF-? and IL-17 by TLR2-deficient mice. Interest-
ingly, IL-17 is a cytokine involved with proinflammatory activity
and increased PMN chemotaxis due to its ability to promote the
synthesis of CXC chemokines (38 – 40). Consistent with the aug-
mented IL-17 production, 72 h after infection increased PMN in-
flux was detected in the alveolar spaces of TLR2?/? mice (our
unpublished data) and these cells could have efficiently controlled
fungal growth but also sustained the synthesis of IL-23 and IL-17

IL-17?CD4? T cells were found in the lungs of these mice after
72 h and 2 wk of P. brasiliensis infection. This Th17-biased
immunity resulted in altered cellular influx to the site of infec-
tion. At weeks 2 and 11 of infection, increased production of
KC, a CXC chemokine involved in PMN chemotaxis, and
augmented influx of neutrophils to the lungs of TLR2-KO mice
were detected; these findings are in agreement with previous
reports showing increased participation of PMN leukocytes in
inflammatory exudates governed by Th17 immunity (38 – 40,
48, 49). Consistent with our results, association of IL-17 syn-
thesis and increased PMN influx to the site of infection was
seen in bacterial pneumonia (50), inflammatory lung disorders
(51), and other fungal infections (31, 52). In addition, the di-
minished presence of MCP-1, a chemokine chemotactic for
macrophages, was associated with decreased numbers of these
cells in the lung cell infiltrates of TLR2-deficient animals.

The Th17-induced PMN accumulation in inflammatory reac-
tions can play antagonistic effects to the hosts, being protective due
to its microbicidal ability or deleterious due to the release of tissue-
damaging components (41). In our model, the higher number of
lung-infiltrating PMN associated with Th17 immunity was respon-
sible, at least partially, by the better fungal clearance observed in
TLR2?/? mice. This was shown by in vivo depletion of PMN cells
that led to increased fungal burdens only in TLR2?/? mice. The
immunoprotective effect of neutrophils was also verified by the
early mortality of PMN-depleted TLR2?/? mice. These data are
consistent with previous findings in murine candidiasis describing
a more severe systemic infection associated with deficient IL-17
production and impaired influx of neutrophils to infected organs
(53) However, as described in other models of prevalent Th17
immunity, we believe that PMN cells exerted a dual effect in mu-
rine PCM. The protection granted by the increased influx and ef-
ficient fungicidal ability was probably accompanied by tissue dam-
age caused by the release of protein-degrading enzymes such as
neutrophil elastase, metalloproteinases, and other cytotoxic com-
pounds as reactive oxygen species (31, 41, 50 –54). Since equiv-
alent fungicidal ability was detected in airway neutrophils from

TLR2?/? and control mice, we believe that the increased number
of PMN cells that migrate to the lungs and not the intrinsic acti-
vation of neutrophils was responsible for the control of fungal
growth.

Despite the control of fungal growth, our data also suggest that
Th17 immunity and PMN cells have also exerted a deleterious
effect in TLR2 ?/? mice. Indeed, the diminished fungal burdens of
TLR2?/? mice were concomitant with pulmonary lesions as
severe as those displayed by WT mice. In both mouse strains
nonorganized inflammatory reactions replaced almost all lung
parenchyma, suggesting that high fungal loads (developed by
WT animals) or prevalent Th17 immunity (mounted by
TLR2?/? mice) have similar deleterious effects to P.
brasiliensis-infected mice.

The phenotypic analysis of lymphocyte subsets performed
after 2 and 11 wk of infection showed a decreased frequency of
CD4? and CD8? T cells in TLR2?/? mice. This fact could be
attributed to the lower fungal burden detected in this mouse
strain or to the Th17-skewed immunity developed by the defi-
cient animals. The early secretion of TGF-? and IL-6 by
TLR2?/? mice appeared to have induced a precocious and
prevalent Th17 immunity which resulted in diminished macro-
phage and T cell migration to the lungs. These cells were, how-
ever, partially replaced by PMN neutrophils which characterize
Th17-mediated inflammatory exudates.

By week 11 of infection, TLR2?/? mice appear to maintain
their prevalent Th17 immunity, whereas WT mice presented
increased fungal burdens associated with augmented production
of IL-10, IL-12, and significant expansion of Tregs. It can be
supposed that those Tregs exerted an enhancing effect on fungal
growth but an inhibitory activity on inflammatory reactions by
down-modulating innate and adaptive immunity. Consistent
with this interpretation, a recent work elegantly demonstrated
the association of Tregs and increased fungal burdens in an
experimental model of PCM using CXCR5 KO mice (55). The
absence of TLR2 associated with decreased differentiation of
Tregs here observed is also consistent with the increased secre-
tion of TGF-?, which, associated with IL-6 (or other proinflam-
matory cytokine), could have inhibited FoxP3 production and
expansion of Tregs (30).

In murine candidiasis, TLR2-deficient mice were shown to de-
velop a more severe infection (56), a fact not subsequently con-
firmed (4, 16). The increased resistance of TLR2-deficient mice
was associated with diminished IL-10 production and a decreased
expansion of Tregs, which led to a more efficient Th1 immunity (4,
16). Similarly to the candidiasis model, PCM in TLR2?/? mice
results in lower fungal loads and decreased expansion of Tregs.
However, expression of TLR2 appears to be protective to pulmo-
nary PCM because of its inhibitory activity on the development of
Th17 immunity and tissue pathology. In addition, the decreased
expansion of Tregs could have contributed to the maintenance of
pathogenic inflammatory reactions.

The prevalent Th17 immunity developed by TLR2-deficient
mice could be explained by the use of different pattern recognition
receptors at the initial phase of infection. Other experimental mod-
els have implicated the use of Dectin-1 or TLR4 in the induction
of Th17 immunity (57–59). Despite the initial pattern recognition
receptor used, our results add a new mechanistic pathway which
can lead to deleterious Th17 immunity in fungal infections in the
absence of TLR2 signaling.

In summary, we have demonstrated for the first time that TLR2
are important innate receptors for P. brasiliensis which appears to
use TLR2 as a virulence mechanism, which facilitates the access of
fungal cells into murine macrophages. Most important, this is the

Abstract: 1 

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) present in innate immune cells recognize pathogen 2 

molecular patterns and influence immunity that control host-parasite interaction. 3 

The objective of this study was to characterize the involvement of TLR4 in the 4 

innate and adaptive immunity to Paraccocidioides brasiliensis, the most important 5 

primary fungal pathogen of Latin America. We compared the responses of 6 

C3H/HeJ mice, which are naturally defective in TLR4 signaling, with C3H/HePas 7 

mice, which express functional receptors, after in vitro and in vivo infection with 8 

P.brasiliensis. Unexpectedly, we verified that TLR4-defective macrophages 9 

infected in vitro with P. brasiliensis presented decreased fungal loads associated 10 

with impaired synthesis of nitric oxide, IL-12 and MCP-1. After intratracheal 11 

infection with one million yeasts, TLR4-defective mice developed reduced fungal 12 

burdens and decreased levels of pulmonary nitric oxide, proinflammatory 13 

cytokines and antibodies. TLR4-competent mice produced elevated levels of IL-12 14 

and TNF-????,,,, besides cytokines of the Th17 pattern indicating a proinflammatory 15 

role for TLR4 signaling.  The more severe infection of TLR4-normal mice resulted 16 

in increased influx of activated macrophages and T cells to the lungs, progressive 17 

control of fungal burdens but impaired expansion of regulatory T cells. In 18 

contrast, TLR4-defective mice were not able of totally clearing their diminished 19 

fungal burdens, associated with deficient activation of T cell immunity and 20 

enhanced development of Treg cells. These divergent patterns of immunity, 21 

however, resulted in equivalent mortality rates indicating that control of elevated 22 

fungal growth mediated by vigorous  inflammatory reactions is as deleterious to 23 

the hosts as low fungal loads inefficiently controlled by limited inflammatory 24 

reactions.  25

INTRODUCTION 1 

 2 

Pathogen recognition receptors (PRRs) are a group of receptors present in the membrane 3 

and cytoplasm of innate immunity cells which recognize the presence of invading 4 

microbes by interacting with conserved pathogen structures, the so called “pathogen 5 

associated molecular patterns” or “PAMP”. This initial event of innate immunity is 6 

crucial to control pathogen growth and to subsequently activate adaptative immunity. 7 

Toll like receptors (TLRs) constitute a major family of pattern recognition molecules 8 

and, like other PRRs, are able to respond to different structural homologies conserved in 9 

many microorganisms (2, 62). The TLRs activation is crucial for many aspects of 10 

microbe elimination, including microbial killing, recruitment of phagocytes to the site of 11 

infection and activation of dendritc cells (DCs) (52). Early TLR activation results in the 12 

production of several inflammatory mediators and the final balance among pro- and 13 

anti-inflammatory components will regulate the type of adaptative immune response. 14 

Recent findings have shown that direct recognition of PAMPs by DCs is critical for 15 

priming appropriate T cell responses resulting in T helper 1 (Th1), Th2  or Th17 16 

immunity (25, 31, 34, 60).  17 

The TLR4 is the key receptor that recognizes bacterial lipopolysaccharides 18 

whereas TLR2 is involved in the interaction with bacterial peptidoglycans and 19 

lipoproteins (66). As described for other microorganisms, TLRs were shown to be 20 

involved in host defense against different fungal pathogens.  In vivo and in vitro studies 21 

demonstrated that Cryptococcus neoformans (7, 67), Candida albicans (43, 45) and 22 

Aspergillus fumigatus (24, 39) may signal through members of the TLR family, mainly 23 

TLR2 and TLR4. Different components of a certain pathogen can be used to stimulate 24 

the immune system. Thus, phospholipomannan of C. albicans is sensed by TLR2 (33) 25

 4 

while O-linked mannans are recognized by TLR4 (44).The contribution of individual 1 

TLRs to the immune response against pathogenic fungi depends on several factors such 2 

as the fungal morphotype, fungal species and route of infection. Activation signals 3 

mediated by innate immunity receptors, however, are not always beneficial to the host 4 

and TLR activation can be used by pathogenic fungi to promote more severe infections 5 

(5, 53). 6 

 Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) is a systemic granulomatous disease caused by 7 

the dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and constitutes de most prevalent 8 

deep mycosis in Latin America (28).  The alveolar macrophages are the first host cells 9 

that interact with P. brasiliensis cells and their activation is fundamental to control 10 

fungal growth. The molecular mechanisms controlling the initial steps of P. brasiliensis 11 

and phagocytes interaction are not well understood. It is known, however, that normal 12 

macrophages are permissive to P. brasiliensis growth while cytokine-activated 13 

macrophages are able to restrain P. brasiliensis multiplication (12).  Complement 14 

receptor 3 (CR3) and mannose receptor were shown to play an important role in the 15 

initial interaction between P. brasiliensis cells and mouse peritoneal macrophages (14, 16 

32, 50). Interestingly, a recent work of our laboratory demonstrated that alveolar 17 

macrophages from susceptible mice (B10.A) are easily activated by P. brasiliensis 18 

infection, and show efficient fungal killing associated with nitric oxide production while 19 

pulmonary macrophages from resistant mice (A/Sn) are poorly activated and present 20 

inefficient killing activity associated with increased levels of TGF-? (49). Despite their 21 

inefficient innate immunity, A/Sn mice develop a balanced Th1/Th2 immunity which 22 

controls fungal growth without intense tissue pathology. 23 

In a previous work, our group demonstrated the influence of TLR2 in pulmonary  24 

PCM (15, 38) . Using TLR2-normal and TLR2-deficient mice we were able to show 25

 5 

that the presence of TLR2 causes more severe in vitro and in vivo P.brasiliensis 1 

infections.  In addition, TLR2 deficiency results in increased Th17 immunity associated 2 

with diminished expansion of Treg cells and increased lung pathology due to 3 

unrestrained inflammatory reactions (38). Characterizing the behavior of dendritic cells 4 

in murine PCM, Ferreira et al. observed an increased expression of TLR2 by dendritic 5 

cells of susceptible, but not resistant mice (26). Moreover, TLR2, TLR-4 and dectin-1 6 

were suggested to be involved in the recognition and internalization of P. brasiliensis 7 

by human monocytes and neutrophils, indicating an important role of these pathogen 8 

receptors in the immune response against the fungus (10).  9 

We decided to investigate the role of TLR4 in murine PCM using in vitro and in 10 

vivo models of infection. Using TLR-competent C3H/HePas and C3H/HeJ mice which 11 

possess a missense mutation in the TLR4 gene, we were able to demonstrate that both, 12 

in vitro and in vivo, TLR4 signaling causes a more severe infection associated with 13 

increased activation of innate and adaptive immunity, but decreased expansion of Treg 14 

cells. This pattern of immunity, however, was not beneficial to the hosts due to the 15 

increased lung injury mediated by inefficient control of inflammatory reactions by Treg 16 

cells. 17

associated with decreased synthesis of NO, IL-12 and MCP-1. Before performing 10 

fungicidal studies, we asked whether the initial interaction between P. brasiliensis 11 

yeasts and peritoneal macrophages from C3H/HeJ and C3H/HePas mice was equivalent.  12

/well), performed in round glass coverlips, were pre-13

1,000 macrophages was counted and the number of ingested and/or adherent yeasts was 17 

determined. As shown in Fig. 1A, when compared with normal macrophages, TLR4-18 

deficient macrophages presented a lower number of associated (ingested/adhered) 19 

yeasts.  20

cytokines and cell homogenates plated for CFU determinations. As can be seen in Fig. 23 

1B, TLR4-signaling resulted in increased recovery of viable yeasts from untreated and 24

TLR4 dysfunction leads to diminished production of proinflammatory and 8 

Th17 cytokines. Cytokines associated with Th1, Th2 and Th17 cells were assessed in 9 

lung homogenates obtained at different periods of infection. The production of type 1 10

Th17-associated (IL-17, IL-6, TGF-? and IL-23) cytokines were studied 96h, 2 and 11 12

antibodies. Although in some fungal infections specific antibodies may have a 20

disease severity (13, 17).  As expression of TLRs were shown to influence B cell 22 

activation (30, 41) we decided to characterize humoral immunity of TLR4-deficient and 23 

normal mice at week 11 postinfection. The less severe infection of TLR4-deficient mice 24 

was associated with decreased production of IgG1, IgG2b and IgM  specific isotypes. 25

Absence of TLR4 signaling does not increase mortality rates but results in 1 

less severe inflammatory reactions in the lungs. To verify the influence of TLR4 2 

deficiency in the disease outcome, mortality of P.brasiliensis infected C3H/HeJ and 3 

C3H/HePas mice was registered daily for a 250-days period, and the median survival
 

4 

time was calculated for each strain. Surprisingly, despite the significant differences in 5 

fungal burdens, no differences between mortality data (p= 0.9) were detected (Fig. 8A). 6 

The mean survival times of C3H/HeJ and C3H/HePas mice were 221 and 203 days, 7 

respectively. At day 250 (35 weeks postinfection), the remaining survivors were 8 

sacrificed and the number of CFUs determined in organs. Compared with other 9 

postinfection periods assayed, lower fungal burdens were detected in both mouse 10 

strains, but TLR4-normal mice remained with higher pulmonary fungal loads than toll-11 

defective mice (Fig. 8B). To further characterize the severity of P.brasiliensis infection, 12 

histopathological examination of lungs was done at week 11 of infection. As can be 13 

seen in Fig. 8C and 8E, a similar pattern of inflammatory reactions was detected in the 14 

lungs of both mouse strains, but more preserved lung tissue was seen in TLR4-defective 15 

mice. The pulmonary tissue presented several confluent or isolated granulomas of 16 

varying sizes containing yeast cells with preserved morphology (Fig. 8D, 8F). Large 17 

aggregates of macrophages, rare epithelioid cells and a poor mantle of lymphocytes 18 

composed the granulomas, which were usually placed in the interlobular septa. Plasma 19 

cells, eosinophils and multinucleated cells were scarcely seen. The total area of lesions 20 

was quantified in histological sections and shown in Fig 8G. At week 11, the areas of 21 

lesions of TLR4-normal mice were significantly larger than that presented by TLR4-22 

deficient mice. Thus, the higher influx of inflammatory cells observed in the lungs of 23 

TLR4-normal mice was concomitant with increased pathology of lung tissue. 24

 15 

The innate immune mechanisms of hosts infected with P.brasiliensis are poorly 1 

defined, but macrophages and their pathogen recognition receptors are thought to play a 2 

crucial role in the initial interaction of this fungus with the immune system (16, 26, 29, 3 

49, 50). Despite several studies with diverse fungal pathogens (16, 43) the role played 4 

by TLRs in paracoccidioidomycosis is still unclear. In a previous report we were able to 5 

show the dual role played by TLR2 in the immunity to P.brasiliensis infection. TLR2 6 

activation prevented uncontrolled inflammatory reactions in pulmonary 7 

paracoccidioidomycosis associated with increased expansion of Th17 cells and 8 

diminished function of Treg cells (38).  9 

Initially we characterized the influence of TLR4 in the phagocytic and fungicidal 10 

ability of macrophages. Both, absence of TLR4 expression by TLR4
-/-

 C57BL/6 mice as 11 

well as defective TLR4 signaling (C3H/HeJ) resulted in deficient P.brasiliensis 12 

ingestion/adherence, and lower fungal loads recovered 48 hs after co-cultivation. In 13 

both deficient mouse strains, lower levels of nitric oxide (and cytokines with C3H/HeJ 14 

cells) were  detected, indicating that the lower CFU counts recovered were not due to 15 

increased activation of phagocytes and enhanced fungal killing, but probably by the 16 

decreased endocytosis of P.brasiliensis yeasts. TLRs usually do not act as phagocytic 17 

receptors but their engagement by pathogen components results in strong activation of 18 

inflammatory responses (8, 9). There are, however, several examples demonstrating that 19 

cell signaling can influence endocytosis and vice-versa (20, 23). Indeed, TLR4 was 20 

shown to actively participate in bacterial phagocytosis (4) and to be rapidly internalized 21 

by human monocytes after in vitro interaction with P.brasiliensis yeasts or A. fumigatus 22 

conidia (10, 21). In addition, a recent paper has clearly demonstrated that TLR4 and 23 

TLR2 synergize with class-A scavenger receptor to mediate phagocytosis of Gram-24 

negative and Gram-positive bacteria, respectively (3). Thus, we can suppose that TLR 25

of proinflammatory pathways which, however, were not sufficient to control the early 2 

increased fungal loads. As equivalent results were obtained with macrophages lacking 3 

TLR4 expression, we believe that TLR4 signaling could have influenced the  4 

phagocytosis mediated by another pathogen receptor. Although our experiments have 5 

not discriminated the main PRR involved in the initial P.brasiliensis recognition, 6 

(particularly due to the number and complexity of components that comprise fungal cell 7 

walls), we have clearly demonstrated that TLR4 participate in the activation of innate 8 

immune cells required to the initial interaction with P.brasiliensis yeasts.  Our in vitro 9 

findings were validated by in vivo experiments, which demonstrated that early in 10 

infection TLR4-normal mice presented higher fungal loads than their TLR4-defective 11 

counterparts and this was accompanied by increased activation of the immune system. 12 

Additional experiments with PRR agonists and antagonists using TLR4 normal and 13 

deficient cells are needed, however, to further clarify the role of TLRs in pulmonary 14 

PCM. 15 

Our in vivo data showed that mice expressing a defective TLR4 developed a less 16 

severe infection associated with lower production of nitric oxide, cytokines and 17 

migration of inflammatory cells to the site of infection. A decreased presence of 18 

activated macrophages expressing CD11b, CD86, CD40 and MHC class II molecules 19 

was concomitant with a reduced synthesis of MCP-1. In addition, the diminished 20 

presence of CD4
+
 T cells and recently activated CD69

+
 CD8

+
 T cells in the lungs of 21 

TLR4-defective mice demonstrates that TLR4 signaling is necessary to the proper 22 

activation of adaptive immunity to P.brasiliensis and enhanced migration of 23 

inflammatory cells into the lungs. Consistent with these observations, several reports 24 

demonstrated that TLR4 signaling is needed to the activation and maturation of 25

cytokines, however, were detected in lung homogenates. The increased production of 3 

IL-12 and TNF-? concomitant with unaltered synthesis of Th2 cytokines (IL-4, IL-5 4 

and IL-10) indicated, however, that TLR4 signaling promoted a cytokine milieu biased 5 

to a proinflammatory balance. This cytokine response could have protected C3H/HePas 6 

mice from high fungal burdens due to the enhanced fungicidal mechanisms of activated 7 

phagocytes. Indeed, in experimental an human PCM, cytokine-activated phagocytes 8 

(mainly by IFN??, IL-12 and TNF-?) were shown to be the most important  effector 9 

cells against P.brasiliensis infection (36, 40, 46, 55). Our data on cytokines production 10 

showed an additional fact not previously reported in PCM. The expression of TLR4 11 

facilitated the expansion of IL-17-producing cells since the levels of IL-17 and other 12 

Th17 associated cytokines (IL-6 and IL-23) appeared in higher levels in the lungs of 13 

TLR4-competent mice. In our previous report, we could verify that absence of TLR2 14 

signaling induced enhanced expansion of Th17 cells and both CD4

displayed intracellular IL-17 (38). Further studies in the TLR4-deficient model will help 16 

us to characterize the phenotype of cells involved in IL-17 production.  17

deficiency can lead to increased expansion of CD4

pathogens (6) we can suppose that Treg cells could have negatively controlled the 25

advantage of low fungal loads conferred by TLR4 deficiency appeared to be negatively 2 

compensated by the deficient T cell immunity and increased numbers of Treg cells 3 

which appear to hamper the total clearance of fungi cells from the lungs. 4 

At week 11 of infection, decreased levels of IL-12 were detected, probably due 5 

to the decreased migration of macrophages to the lungs. Interestingly, in C3H/HeJ mice  6 

decreased levels of IL-17 were concomitant diminished levels of TGF-? indicating that 7 

another cytokine or costimulatory signal have participated in the increased expansion of 8 

Treg cells (27).  9 

As expression of TLRs were shown to influence B cell activation (41), we 10 

decided to analyze the levels of anti-P.brasiliensis isotypes in our model and observed 11 

an impaired humoral immune response in TLR4-defective mice. At week 11 of 12 

infection (Fig. 7) TLR4-deficient mice produced lower levels of IgG1, IgG2b and IgM 13 

specific antibodies. This could be due to the diminished fungal loads or the decreased 14 

production of cytokines observed in this mouse strain. Alternatively, as almost all TLRs 15 

ligands were recently shown to induce expansion and differentiation of B cells (30), we 16 

can suppose that TLR4 agonists present in P.brasiliensis yeasts could have exerted an 17 

stimulatory effect on B cells of TLR4-normal mice, resulting in increased humoral 18 

immunity. Independently of the mechanisms used, this is the first demonstration on the 19 

stimulatory role of TLR4 in the humoral immunity of P.brasiliensis infected hosts. 20 

TLR4 recognizes lipopolysaccharide (LPS) of Gram-negative bacteria and favor 21 

Th1immunity due to the increased ability of LPS-stimulated DCs to produce IL-12 and 22 

TNF-? (51). In some fungal infections, however, cell wall polysaccharides have been 23 

reported to function as TLRs agonists (42, 63). To our knowledge, no studies in 24 

paracoccidioidomycosis have addressed the characterization of TLR agonists. Although 25

LPS or LPS-like components in P.brasiliensis were not characterized, a few 1 

investigations have described the presence of polysaccharides, lipids and glycolipids in 2 

P.brasiliensis cell walls (35, 61). The alcali-soluble fraction of P.brasiliensis cell walls 3 

was shown to contain a high proportion of galactomannan (35) and is tempting to 4 

suppose that this component could play a role in TLR4 activation.   5 

Dectin and TLR4 signaling by microbial agonists have been reported to induce 6 

prevalent expansion of Th17 cells (1, 22, 33, 37).  In our model, mice that possessed 7 

functional TLR4 were shown to have increased levels of IL-17 and other Th17 8 

associated cytokines in their lungs. Although not investigated in the present work, IL-9 

17-mediated immunity was shown to exert deleterious or protective effects in infectious 10 

processes (54, 58).  Actually, Th17 immunity can protect hosts due to its 11 

proinflammatory and chemotactic effect to PMN cells. Conversely, the enhanced 12 

oxidative metabolism and increased synthesis of metalloproteinases can result in tissue 13 

pathology and detrimental effect to the hosts (11, 68, 69). In our previous work on the 14 

role of TLR2 in pulmonary PCM we could demonstrate the dual role of Th17 immunity. 15 

The increased presence of inflammatory neutrophils conferred immunoprotection by 16 

reducing fungal loads but also resulted in tissue pathology equivalent to that induced by 17 

higher fungal burdens (38). 18 

Mortality studies, unexpectedly, demonstrated that TLR4 signaling does not 19 

influence disease outcome since TLR4-competent and deficient mice presented 20 

equivalent survival times. In the course of the disease, both mouse strains were able to 21 

control fungal growth and to develop granulomatous reactions. However, the higher 22 

fungal loads, the enhanced T cell immunity and the lower expansion of Treg cells 23 

resulted in more extensive inflammatory lesions which exerted a deleterious effect to 24 

the lungs of TLR4-normal mice. On the other hand, the inefficient T cell immunity of 25

TLR4-deficient mice, tightly controlled by Treg cells, was not sufficient to totally clear 1 

the diminished fungal loads of TLR4-defective mice abolishing the initial advantage 2 

conferred by their defective phagocytic ability. In sum, our findings indicate that high 3 

fungal loads accompanied by enhanced inflammatory responses mediated by 4 

uncontrolled T cell immunity are equivalent to low fungal loads poorly controlled by 5 

deficient T cell response. Both mechanisms of immunity result in the chronic evolution 6 

of infection and equivalent mortality rates.       7
